awd_titl_txt: CAS: Photoinduced Interfacial Charge Transfers with Organic Sensitizers using Low Energy Photons and Fundamental Physical Organic Design Concepts
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Jared Delcamp and Nathan Hammer of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Mississippi are developing new classes of organic dye molecules that exhibit interesting light-matter interactions. The goal of this research is to design organic dyes that absorb low-energy light to enable the design of higher-performing electronic devices such as night vision technologies, infrared cameras, secure display technologies, solar cells including transparent ones integrable with buildings, solar batteries, and artificial photosynthetic systems. This project relies on interdisciplinary research utilizing organic, inorganic, materials, and physical chemistry.  To encourage STEM involvement, outreach activities to the general public and student groups with large populations of underrepresented minorities are planned. A yearly summer research program brings STEM students onto campus to conduct independent research related to this award. 

Near-infrared absorbing organic dyes capable of undergoing interfacial charge separation at metal oxide interfaces are needed to advance a number of emerging technologies. Metal oxide bound organic dyes that absorb low energy photons (>800 nm) and subsequently undergo charge separation in high quantum yields are rare. Systems in these regions are often limited in utility by excited-state and charge separated state lifetimes. The study of fundamental physical organic chemistry is needed to enable the rational design of systems using low energy photons. In this project, four types of systems are studied at interfaces: (1) dyes with delocalized charge states after electron transfer to metal oxides, (2) dyes with excited-state aromaticity for prolonging excited states to promote higher quantum yields of interfacial photoinduced charge separation, (3) double cross-conjugated dyes for lower energy photon absorptions, and (4) Near-infrared absorbing chromophores incorporating proaromatic functionality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Designing strategies to effectively use low energy photons (>800 nm) with organic optoelectronic materials is a critical challenge with substantial transformative capacity. Specifically, photoinduced charge separation at metal oxide-organic molecule interfaces using near-infrared (NIR) photons is an area which could have tremendous impact on solar cells, solar batteries, night vision technologies, NIR cameras, photosensors, and photoelectrochemical cells including artificial photosynthesis systems. The goal of this research program was to use physical organic chemistry concepts to rationally design deeper NIR absorbing organic materials with precisely controlled energetics for low energy photon conversion to charge separated states across organic dye-MO interfaces.

Intellectual Merit: A total of sixteen new designer dyes were discovered during the project period that can convert >800 nm photons to electric potentials. Many of these dyes exhibit good quantum yields (≥70%) when used with TiO2. These results were disseminated in a total of eleven peer-reviewed publications that credit this award. One accomplishment includes discovering the highest photocurrent generating squaraine dyes known in the literature. Charge separation durations at 0.1 s using the squaraine dyes in functional dye sensitized solar cells that produced electricity beyond 900 nm was demonstrated. This result is exceptional at TiO2 and exceeded the project target of 0.01 s. This long-lived charge separation is likely the direct result of proaromatic behavior, which was engineered into many of the dyes. Doubly cross-conjugated dyes systems were also developed that exhibit behavior at >1000 nm and quantum yields as high as 80%.

Broader Impacts: In addition to publications and advancements in energy harvesting in the near-infrared, a total of seven graduate students and two undergraduate students were directly supported by this award. Faculty and students presented seminars about light harvesting and near-infrared energy conversion to the Ole Miss Physical Chemistry Summer Research Program REU, at regional and national conferences, and to university chemistry departments.


Last Modified: 10/30/2024
Modified by: Nathan Hammer
